newsitem.title: UNITED NATIONS: Turkish Cypriot says property issue being exploited.
newsitem.headline: Turkish Cypriot says property issue being exploited.

text.p: Turkish Cypriot representative Osman Ertug has accused Cypriot U.N. envoy Nicos Agathocleous of exploiting the issue of abandoned property for propaganda purposes.

In a letter to Secretary-General Kofi Annan circulated on Wednesday, Ertug referred to a recent call by Agathocleous for the U.N. chief to prevent the sale of two hotels in the Turkish-held north of the island that he said were owned by Greek Cypriots.

"The issue of abandoned property is common to both communities," Ertug said, referring to the virtual partition of the island since 1974, when troops from Turkey took control of the north after a coup in Nicosia backed by the junta ruling Greece at the time.

"The Turkish Cypriot community has left a comparable amount of immovable property in the south as the Greek Cypriot community has left in the north," said Ertug, who represents the Turkish Cypriot community in dealings with the United Nations.
This was a matter to be taken up at inter-communal talks in the framework of a bi-communal, bi-zonal federal settlement, he added.

"The exploitation of this issue by the Greek Cypriot side for propaganda puropses is clearly aimed at prejudicing a bi-zonal settlement, which has been universally accepted as a fair and realistic solution," he said.

"As regards the sale of immovable property in the north, this is totally within the authority and jurisdiction of the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus," he said, referring to the state proclaimed in 1983 but recognised only by Ankara.

"It should also be pointed out that the Greek Cypriot administration, which is guilty of confiscating Turkish Cypriot properties and driving the Turkish Cypriot population into 3 percent of the island's territory between 1963-74, is currently allowing the use, development and even transfer of Turkish Cypriot properties in the south," Ertug added.
